my:Details.my:Title: Recovery of Persons from Enclosed/Confined Spaces

my:Hazard.my:Description: Training in realistic conditions, lifting and lowering casualties
my:Hazard.my:ControlMeasures: First thing to do is monitor confined space and training atmosphere before the operation of rescue take place. It must be assumed that the atmosphere in the space is unsafe and the rescue team must not enter unless wearing breathing apparatus. In such situations if the space allows, the Rescue Tripod Winch should be used. During drills only mannequins/"dummy's" to be used as casualties. Allocation of personnel to relieve or back-up those first into the space should be part of the plan.

At all the times PPE should be used accordingly. Equipment for testing the atmosphere should be at all the times checked and ready for use at any time. All breathing apparatus, rescue harnesses, lifelines, resuscitation equipment and any other equipment for use in, or in connection with entry into enclosed/confined spaces should be used.

my:Hazard.my:Description: Personal injuries: falling, exposure to irrespirable atmosphere
my:Hazard.my:ControlMeasures: Proper PPE should be warn at all the times. Testing of atmosphere before entering an enclosed/confined space is a "Must". Ventilations should be taken in consideration where possible.

my:Hazard.my:Description: Possible injuries of the rescued person
my:Hazard.my:ControlMeasures: A stretcher is the ideal means of transporting a casualty. Where the stretcher is too large or not available, the following methods can be used: a) Forward drag/rescue crawl/neck drag (casualty without hand injury): Tie the casualty's arms securely at both wrists with triangular bandages or pass a belt/rope under casualty near armpits. Kneel astride the casualty pass your head between the casualty's arms. Straighten your arms to lift casualty. Drag out the casualty by crawling and pushing your feet or drag the casualty by pushing your feet. b) Cross-chest method (For unconscious casualty with minor injuries): Lift the casualty to a sitting position. Sit behind the casualty with both legs apart. Cross the casualty's hands and place them across his chest. With fingers on shoulders, insert your arm under the casualty's armpit and hold the outer arm of the casualty. Drag out the casualty backwards. c) Collar pull method: Casualty's head is positioned in direction of exit d) Leg pull method: Casualty's legs are in direction of exit and casualty cannot be repositioned
